awd_titl_txt: Elucidating essential factors for production of recombinant secreted proteins through proteomics
awd_abstract_narration:
Mammalian cells are used to produce valuable therapeutic and industrial proteins, such as monoclonal antibodies, enzymes, cytokines and vaccines. Many important proteins are difficult to produce because they are not easily secreted from cells. This project will decipher the molecular mechanisms controlling protein secretion. Understanding these mechanisms will enable strategies for engineering protein secretion and improving production of high-value proteins. Advanced machine learning approaches will also be developed to guide cell engineering. As part of this project, local high school students will be trained in a summer program focused on biological big data analytics. 

This project will establish a novel method to identify and quantify the host cell secretory pathway machinery that directly regulates protein secretion. The primary focus will be on monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and related Fc-fusion molecules of primary importance to the biotherapeutic industry. Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) will be measured in situ between the mAbs/related proteins and the cellular secretory pathway machinery. This will be done using proximity biotinylation with our Fc-mediated biotinylation by antibody recognition (FcBAR) method. This project will (1) establish a method for measuring essential PPIs for a secreted protein and identify PPIs correlating with secretion rate. This method will be applied to Rituximab-producing CHO (Chinese hamster ovary) cells. (2) A novel systems biology analysis approach will be applied to unravel how changes in PPI strength impact secretion. This computational framework will help define roles of interacting proteins and prioritize PPIs for further study. (3) Expression of these interaction factors will be modulated to validate their role in mAb secretion. (4) Finally, product-specific vs. more general PPIs used for protein secretion will be identified by quantifying PPIs for additional Fc-fusion proteins and comparing how much the secretory pathway needs differ across secreted proteins. The tools developed by this project will guide host cell engineering for biomanufacturing of diverse proteins and will provide deep insights into the functions of the mammalian secretory pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the Univ. of Calif., U.C. San Diego

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This grant funded the development of an innovative approach to identify the essential cellular machinery needed to make antibodies, which account for more than half of the top medications by sales. This work aimed to develop and deploy the approach on Rituximab and multiple other therapeutic proteins. We successfully applied it to identify the protein-protein interactions in CHO cells as they produce Rituximab, an important biotherapeutic protein. An algorithm based on queueing theory was developed to contextualize the data and identify where in the CHO secretory pathway the therapeutic protein synthesis was being blocked in CHO clones that expressed limited quantities of the medication. The manuscripts for this work are nearing completion and will be published soon. In addition, a couple therapeutic cytokines (IL-15 and IL-2) have been assayed to identify the cellular machinery needed for their synthesis in CHO and immune cells (manuscripts in preparation). The method was also applied to study the production of fetuin-B, and we identified a large number of host cell proteins that are involved in its synthesis, folding, glycosylation, and intracellular trafficking. In that study, we also developed a computational algorithm for the analysis of the proteomic and RNA-Seq data in CHO cells. The algorithm is called secCellFie (see Masson et al. Metabolic Engineering, 2023), and the data were published for public access. 

Broader Impact: The fcBAR method was successfully transferred to another academic lab to study cytokine secretion. In addition, it was successfully transferred to a major pharmaceutical company, wherein they have identified the cellular machinery needed for the synthesis of one of there model therapeutics (manuscript in preparation). The work funded by this grant will continue to be applied to study the production of subunit vaccines in CHO cells and  the mechanisms involved in protein glycosylation. Furthermore once the full protocol is published, we anticipate many others will use the approach. 

This work also supported the training of one research associate who moved to a career at Pfizer, a PhD student who went on to a job at Grail Bio, and a PhD student who now works at Lilly. It also supported a current PhD student, and a postdoctoral fellow. The trainees included under-represented minority graduate students.

Finally, an outreach protgram on biological big-data analysis was developed. While its implementation was delayed due to the pandemic, a trial run was successfully done, wherein the participants were trained in big-data analytics. From this, one high-school participant was included on a resulting publication, and a local high school teacher was also trained. Future cohorts will open up the program to additional high school students for summer workshops. 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: Nathan E Lewis
